newsitem.title: USA: Integrated Systems falters after downgrade.
newsitem.headline: Integrated Systems falters after downgrade.

text.p: Shares of Integrated Systems Inc fell about 40 percent after Hambrecht & Quist downgraded the stock to hold from buy.
Integrated Systems dropped seven to 10-1/8 and was one of the most heavily-traded Nasdaq issues.
Hambrect & Quist analyst Sheila Ennis said she downgraded Integrated Systems due to the slower-than-expected rollout of its Prism Plus product line.
"I don't believe in any way that this is 'game over,' but I'm just concerned that it could take a little longer to get the tools out there," Ennis said.

The downgrade compounded news of Integrated System's expected earnings shortfall. Integrated Systems said late Monday it expects its fourth quarter and fiscal 1997 earnings will fall short of analysts' expectations.
The company said in a statement it expects primary earnings per share for the fourth quarter of between $0.10 and $0.11 per share.

Earnings per share for the full year are estimated to be between $0.31 and $0.32, including merger related expenses. Excluding the merger related expenses, primary earnings per share for the year would be $0.46 to $0.47.
On a consensus basis, analysts expected the company would earn $0.19 a share for the fourth quarter and $0.55 a share for the year, according to First Call.
Ennis said she trimmed her earnings estimates to $0.46 from $0.56 for the 1997 fiscal year ended February, and to $0.60 from $0.84 for 1998.
Integrated Systems, based in Santa Clara, Calif., makes software development tools that let computer chipmakers embed software on their microchips.
